text: the rallying cry is we are the people
the banners reads against religious
fanaticism
this is pegida a group that's been
protesting here in dresden for weeks now
but this is the biggest rally so far I
lived what I've experienced what my
daughter is experiencing at school Islam
is not a religion of peace and we have
to deal with it our life as we know it
in Germany is threatened by it the
protestors say they are defending
Christian values but critics say they
are promoting right-wing extremism it's
about the asylum seekers they do not
make themselves at home here they walk
around hooded with slits for eyes that's
not done here we have a different
culture and they have to assimilate
Germany is facing a wave of incoming
migrants this year it expects 200,000
asylum claims more than any other
country in the world many were from
Syria Iraq and Afghanistan the protests
in Dresden have sparked counter protests
in many cities with the largest here in
Munich yet sneak ashley's League
muskegon produces an event against
pegida but also to send out a signal
that you can also do it the other way
around
instead of excluding people you can
invite them in the sheer number of
demonstrators gathering on both sides
are forcing a public discussion on
immigration
a debate which can no longer be ignored
Laura Westbrook BBC News
